item.title: DIY home Security System with an Old iPhone
item.description: Building a DIY Home Security System with an Old iPhone and Some Determination Look, I’ll be honest with you - I was genuinely worried. Our new neighborhood has been seeing break-in attempts every other day. Car break-ins, people trying doorknobs at 2 AM… the whole deal. I needed something to monitor my driveway at night, and I needed it fast. Commercial security cameras? They wanted ‚Ç¨200+ per camera, plus subscription fees.

item.description: _______________ < Im not rabbit!! > --------------- \ ^__^ \ (oo)\_______ (__)\ )\/\ ||----w | || || Today at work, had to demonstrate a proof of concept (POC) related to message queues, so need to spin-up a rabbitmq server. “Play with Docker” come to the rescue. In couple of minutes environment is up and ready. docker run -d \ --hostname rabbit-host \ --name rabbit-container \ -p 80:15672 \ -p 5672:5672 \ -e RABBITMQ_DEFAULT_USER="rabbit" \ -e RABBITMQ_DEFAULT_PASS="carrot" \ rabbitmq:3-management PORT Description 15672 RabbitMQ Management console uses PORT 15672 for RabbitMQ version 3.

item.description: üê≥ Prerequisite Make sure you have already created a Docker Hub account. PWD This post is about “Play with Docker” chrome-extension. Play with Docker(PWD) by itself is a simple, interactive and fun playground to learn Docker. This will give you a throwaway *nix shell, in which you can safely play with docker. The extension adds a “Try in PWD” button on any Docker Hub image page. Here is a short demo of the same.
